title: The Pomodoro Technique
summary: A time management method that uses timed intervals to improve focus and productivity.
content: The Pomodoro Technique is a time management method developed by Francesco Cirillo in the late 1980s. It uses a timer to break work into intervals, traditionally 25 minutes in length, separated by short breaks.
steps: Choose a task you want to work on
Set a timer for 25 minutes (one 'pomodoro')
Work on the task until the timer rings
Take a short 5-minute break
Every 4 pomodoros, take a longer 15-30 minute break
tips: Keep a distraction list nearby to jot down interrupting thoughts
If interrupted, record what caused it and restart the pomodoro
Adjust the interval length to match your attention span

title: Active Recall
summary: Strengthen memory by actively stimulating recall rather than passive review.
content: Active recall is a learning principle that involves actively stimulating memory during learning. Instead of passively reading or highlighting, you test yourself on the material.
steps: Read or learn the material once
Close your notes and try to recall key points
Write down or speak aloud what you remember
Check your answers against the source material
Focus extra attention on items you couldn't recall
tips: Use flashcards to implement active recall
Test yourself before looking at answers
Space out your practice sessions over time

title: Spaced Repetition
summary: Review material at increasing intervals to move information into long-term memory.
content: Spaced repetition is a learning technique that incorporates increasing intervals of time between reviews of previously learned material. This method exploits the psychological spacing effect.
steps: Learn new material initially
Review after 1 day
Review again after 3 days
Review after 1 week
Review after 2 weeks, then monthly
tips: Use apps like Anki that implement spaced repetition algorithms
Be consistent with your review schedule
Combine with active recall for maximum effectiveness

title: The Feynman Technique
summary: Learn anything deeply by teaching it in simple terms.
content: Named after physicist Richard Feynman, this technique involves explaining a concept in simple language as if teaching it to someone with no background knowledge. If you can't explain it simply, you don't understand it well enough.
steps: Choose a concept to learn
Explain it in simple terms as if teaching a child
Identify gaps in your explanation
Go back to the source material to fill gaps
Simplify your explanation further using analogies
tips: Use analogies and simple examples
Avoid jargon - use everyday language
Actually teach someone else if possible

title: Mind Mapping
summary: Visualize relationships between concepts using diagrams.
content: Mind mapping is a visual thinking tool that helps structure information, making it easier to analyze, comprehend, synthesize, and recall. Start with a central idea and branch out with related concepts.
steps: Start with the main topic in the center
Draw branches for major subtopics
Add smaller branches for related details
Use colors and images to enhance memory
Connect related branches with lines
tips: Use colors to categorize information
Include images and symbols where possible
Keep branches to single keywords when possible

title: Chunking Information
summary: Break large amounts of information into smaller, manageable groups.
content: Chunking is a strategy for making more efficient use of short-term memory by grouping information. By combining individual pieces of information into larger, meaningful units, you can remember more.
steps: Identify the information you need to learn
Look for patterns or categories
Group related items together
Create meaningful connections between chunks
Practice recalling chunks as units
tips: Phone numbers use chunking (555-123-4567)
Create acronyms from first letters
Find patterns in seemingly random information

title: Optimizing Your Study Environment
summary: Create an environment that promotes focus and minimizes distractions.
content: Your physical study environment significantly impacts your ability to focus and retain information. A well-organized, distraction-free space can dramatically improve your study sessions.
steps: Choose a dedicated study space
Ensure good lighting (natural if possible)
Minimize noise or use consistent background sound
Keep your phone out of sight
Have all necessary materials within reach
tips: Consider noise-canceling headphones
Keep your study area clean and organized
Use website blockers during study time
Experiment to find what works for you

title: Interleaved Practice
summary: Mix different topics or problem types during practice sessions.
content: Interleaving involves mixing different topics, subjects, or types of problems during a single study session, rather than focusing on one topic at a time (blocked practice).
steps: Identify 2-4 related topics to study
Alternate between topics during your session
Don't switch too frequently (10-15 min minimum)
Include practice problems from multiple topics
Review connections between topics
tips: This feels harder initially but improves long-term retention
Particularly effective for math and sciences
Helps you recognize which approach to use for different problems

title: Sleep and Learning
summary: Understand how sleep impacts memory consolidation and learning.
content: Sleep plays a crucial role in memory consolidation. During sleep, your brain processes and consolidates information learned during the day, transferring it to long-term memory.
steps: Aim for 7-9 hours of sleep per night
Maintain a consistent sleep schedule
Avoid screens 1 hour before bed
Review important material before sleeping
Don't cram - spread learning over multiple days
tips: Naps can help consolidate learning (20-30 min ideal)
Sleep-deprived learning is significantly less effective
Morning review after sleep reinforces memory

title: Cornell Note-Taking System
summary: A systematic format for organizing and reviewing notes effectively.
content: The Cornell Note-Taking System divides your page into sections for notes, cues, and summary, making review more efficient and promoting active recall.
steps: Divide your page into 3 sections: cues (left), notes (right), summary (bottom)
During class, take notes in the main section
After class, add key terms/questions in the cue column
Write a brief summary at the bottom
Review by covering notes and using cues to recall
tips: Leave space between notes for later additions
Use abbreviations to keep up during lectures
Review notes within 24 hours for best retention
